image.altText: A graphic showing a woman's face over the cliffs of Point Cartwright.

props.synopsis: For nearly 27 years, the family of Meaghan Rose have been trying to prove she was murdered. Now, the ABC can reveal fresh details about her suspected killer.

title.children: Police believe a cold case murder suspect could be hiding 'anywhere in Australia'. They want your help to find him

image.altText: An image showing Steven Miles and David Crisafulli with watermarked police car sirens behind their heads

props.synopsis: Premier Steven Miles has conceded his government is heading for defeat after the latest poll result delivered bad news ahead of the October state election.

title.children: Queensland's premier is changing strategy ahead of the election after latest poll spells bad news for Labor

image.altText: A man in a suit standing outside links arms with a woman and gazes at her, while she smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: In a statement, Buckingham Palace says the King's doctors are "pleased with his progress", 12 weeks after it revealed the monarch's diagnosis.

title.children: King Charles to resume public duties, but cancer fight not over

image.altText: A graphic of a skull and crossbones against a backdrop of newspapers clippings.

props.synopsis: American journalist Deborah Vankin can still recall sitting down one day to read her own obituary. Her search to uncover who was behind it, unearthed a cottage industry of spammy websites run by 'obit pirates'.

title.children: 'People with malicious intent, they are capitalising on this': Is this the world's weirdest scam?

image.altText: An older man in a beanie and spectacles, smiling warmly.

props.synopsis: A teenager kept his eyes lowered, occasionally glancing up at the screen, as footage of his deadly attack on a 75-year-old man was played to a court.

title.children: CCTV presented in court shows teen 'steeling' himself before fatal Toowoomba taxi rank attack

image.altText: An aerial shot of a man in a brown suit stacking rifles on top of each other on a table.

props.synopsis: Police officers will soon be able to access near real-time information on firearms and who owns them after the federal government committed hundreds of millions of dollars to implement a national firearms register.

title.children: The Wieambilla attack reignited calls for a national firearms register. $160 million will see it eventuate

image.altText: Queensland Police Service Senior Constable David Masters smiles and gives the thumbs up.

props.synopsis: The police officer was hit and killed by a stolen car while he was laying road spikes in an attempt to stop the vehicle on the Bruce Highway in 2021.

title.children: Woman accused of murdering Senior Constable David Masters in 'mad cop chase' granted bail

image.altText: ding xuan poses for pictures

props.synopsis: As young people in China feel the squeeze of cost of living and social pressures, many are looking to the country's forgotten older cities where they can buy a home for the price of rent in a megacity and pursue the kind of life they want, not one forced upon them.

title.children: Xuan bought a $6,000 apartment in an old Chinese city so she could 'lie flat' and escape the rat race

image.altText: A crowd of mostly women gather outside, holding signs, one reads ENOUGH IS ENOUGH in red text

props.synopsis: Australians will march this weekend in rallies around the country calling for an end to violence against women. Haven't we marched enough?

title.children: How long will women be marching in the street asking not to be murdered?

image.altText: A composite image with a red bug on the left and a man in a greenhouse on the right.

props.synopsis: James Hill is breeding billions of tiny blind predatory mites that are packed on ice and posted to strawberry farms in the battle against destructive sap-sucking insects.

title.children: The tiny, blind, predatory mite engaged in a microscopic battle for one of Australia's favourite fruits

image.altText: a ripped bodybuilder flexes his chest

props.synopsis: While only doctors can prescribe it in Australia, bodybuilders have begun experimenting with Ozempic.

title.children: 'Revolutionary' weight loss drug tempts bodybuilders, raises alarm for eating disorders

image.altText: Two images of women, one of them is generated by AI.

props.synopsis: Experts have warned that generative artificial intelligence is now capable of producing images of faces that appear more human than actual faces. So what does this mean for the future of the internet?

title.children: Can you spot which of these faces is generated by AI? Probably not — here's why

image.altText: A palm tree and other green foliage with buildings, a bay and headland in the background.

props.synopsis: Pacific Island nations are looking abroad for workers, and taking control of labour mobility schemes at home, as they look to address labour shortages hitting employers. But experts say it's too early to say whether they're succeeding.

title.children: Vanuatu is importing its own foreign workers as labourers move to Australia and NZ for higher pay

props.synopsis: A debate that has largely been framed in terms of freedom of speech has become conflated with a whole range of issues that now challenge us: from social cohesion, to terrorism, to domestic violence.

title.children: From domestic violence, to terrorism and war, social media is a thread that connects all the issues that now challenge us

image.altText: Mass housing site

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner has hit out at plans to turn the controversial Pinkenba quarantine facility into a police training centre rather than repurposing it for the homeless.

title.children: Brisbane Lord Mayor 'heartbroken' by decision to turn Pinkenba quarantine facility to police training centre

image.altText: A composite image of Peter FitSimons, wearing a red bandana, and Bruce Lehrmann in a suit and tie, wearing glasses.

props.synopsis: Former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann is ordered to pay thousands of dollars to journalist Peter FitzSimons for costs incurred in Mr Lehrmann's failed defamation case.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann agrees to pay more than $4,000 to journalist Peter FitzSimons to cover costs incurred during defamation trial

image.altText: A woman in a clothing shop sorts through garments hanging from a wall.

props.synopsis: A regional Victorian initiative dedicated to providing new clothing to vulnerable people is struggling to keep up with demand as donations from its retail partners decrease.

title.children: Clothing donations threadbare as retailers tighten belts amid rising demand

image.altText: Woman cooking  in a kitchen

props.synopsis: With consumers paying more for extra virgin olive oil at the supermarket, chef Kristin Bacon shares her favourite alternatives that won't break the bank.

title.children: The price of olive oil has skyrocketed. Here's what a chef says you can use instead

image.altText: Four CCTV panels of a woman walkign through the door of a shop in a coat carrying a bag

props.synopsis: Journalist Jill Dando was at the height of her career and preparing for a fast-approaching wedding when she was murdered in 1999. Now 25 years later, there are still unanswered questions.

title.children: One of the BBC's most popular presenters was 'assassinated on her doorstep in broad daylight' more than two decades ago

image.altText: A young man poses for a photo on a cliff face, with mountains behind him.

props.synopsis: Ben Cohen, who was falsely identified as the person behind the Bondi Junction stabbing attack by the Seven network, has settled his defamation case.

title.children: Man wrongly identified as Bondi Junction attacker by Seven settles defamation case with the network

image.altText: Harvey Weinstein dressed in a suit, sitting in a court room

props.synopsis: The ruling by a New York high court has been called a major step back for survivors of sexual abuse, with some fearing it could deter other victims from coming forward in similar cases.

title.children: Rose McGowan, Ashley Judd and #MeToo founder react to the overturning of Harvey Weinstein's rape conviction

image.altText: Two police officers in tactical gear stand on a street with their backs to the camera

props.synopsis: Court documents have revealed a 14-year-old boy charged with terrorism-related offences as part of an investigation in to the Wakeley Church stabbing was on conditional bail for a gun possession charge at the time of his arrest.

title.children: 14-year-old facing terror-related charges was already before courts on gun possession charges when granted conditional bail

image.altText: A uniformed police officers stands next to a forensics investigator dressed in a blue suit.

props.synopsis: A 26-year-old man, who was gardening when a fight allegedly broke out with his elderly neighbours, has had his matter briefly mentioned in a Brisbane court after being charged with murder and manslaughter.

title.children: Police say man was gardening when fight broke out with elderly neighbours and one was killed

image.altText: Funeral of Faraz Tahir

props.synopsis: The security guard who died trying to save shoppers from a knife attack at Bondi Junction Westfield is being remembered as a hero at funeral service in north west Sydney.

title.children: Faraz Tahir, security guard who tried to stop Bondi attacker, remembered as a national hero

image.altText: Daria Saville looks frustrated sitting on her bench

props.synopsis: Daria Saville's luck finally runs out at the Madrid Open as Australia's sole woman representative in the big clay-court event is knocked out  for a second time in four days.

title.children: Daria Saville knocked out of Madrid Open for the second time in four days

image.altText: A ref holding his hands in the air, sending a payer to the sin-bin, who looks upset

props.synopsis: Parramatta coach Brad Arthur has called Maika Sivo's forearm to the head of Manly's Reuben Garrick "dumb" as the Eels collapse for the second time in seven days.

title.children: 'Just stupid': Sivo sin-binned for 'egregious' forearm as Parramatta capitulate again

image.altText: Sam Powell-Pepper grimaces as club doctors help him from the field

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide get the points over the Saints at Adelaide Oval — but a string of injuries to key players including a concussion to Aliir Aliir leaves the Power with personnel issues.

title.children: Power await news on Powell-Pepper, Rozee as win over Saints comes at a high cost

image.altText: A composite images of book covers: Caledonian Road, Martyr, The Spoiled Heart, White Cockatoo Flowers, Bullet Paper Rock

props.synopsis: Get lost in these new books — including a posthumous release from a beloved Australian writer, an insouciant short story collection and a thumping evisceration of British culture.

title.children: The best new books our avid readers and critics read in April

image.altText: A sign outside Rockingham General Hospital.

props.synopsis: The body of a 30-year-old woman is found in the bedroom of a fire-damaged home in the southern Perth suburb of Warnbro, with police treating her death as suspicious.

title.children: Woman's body found in Perth home damaged by fire, police treating death as 'murder'

image.altText: A sad man sits on a bench

props.synopsis: Roy Cristuta felt shame and despair when he got a knock at the door from two police officers who had come to take his roosters following noise complaints to council. He's hoping the premier can intervene as he did with Molly the magpie.

title.children: Roy was distraught when police seized his beloved roosters, saying 'I have failed as a father'

image.altText: A baker is photographed through a bakery window as he bakes baguettes

props.synopsis: Competing baguettes in the annual bread-making competition were evaluated for taste, look, texture, airiness and the quality of the baking.

title.children: Paris crowns a new king of the crusty, long bread in its annual 'Grand Prix de la baguette'

image.altText: A girl leans against a wall with a soccer ball.

props.synopsis: Young African women face some cultural barriers around playing sport, but last year's groundbreaking Women's World Cup has opened a conversation in the community.

title.children: Opia used to sit in the park watching her brother play soccer. Now she's showing her own skills

image.altText: Security and military personnel guard a street while ambulance crews work behind them.

props.synopsis: Ahlam Albashir had been previously identified as the person who planted the bomb in Istanbul's main shopping street packed with shoppers and tourists.

title.children: Woman sentenced to life in prison over 2022 Istanbul bombing that killed six

image.altText: A crashed plane with a damaged nose is on sand and taped off as an emergency services work nearby.

props.synopsis: The light plane crash happened at a major airport in Perth's southern suburbs, with the sole person on board rushed to hospital with serious injuries.

title.children: Man seriously injured after crashing plane at Perth's Jandakot Airport
